awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Software for Developing Consumer-Driven Health Care Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is that the technology provides health care systems with a very accurate view of what their patients experience during health care encounters - what is going well and importantly, what specific problems are frustrating patients. With this insight, providers are able to quickly and efficiently resolve issues. Patients are increasingly active in deciding where they receive care.  As health care spending declines, providers find themselves competing for patients. To attract patients and drive market share, health systems must deliver not just excellent clinical care but also positive patient experiences.  Patients that have a negative health care encounter often choose to go elsewhere.  When they do, providers lose margin.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project addresses the industry need for better insight on how to quickly and efficiently improve patient experiences.  Surveys which are the norm in health care fail to deliver service failure details.  The company's software goes beyond current text analysis solutions by automating the classification of patient feedback based on the ideas and sentiment expressed by patients. These results are converted into precise analytics and displayed in dashboards so front-line managers can quickly identify problems and make rapid improvements in patient experiences.  Previously the company demonstrated the technical feasibility of its software by focusing on a narrow set of providers.  This research will refine the software so that it is capable of analyzing patient feedback across a wide range of health care organizations. What operational changes will have the greatest, positive impact on patient loyalty and market share?  Results from this project will answer that question for a broad range of health care organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
PatientsVoices' goal is to make it easy for health systems to improve patient experiences by using insight that is readily available in qualitative feedback to identify the issues that are frustrating patients. The initial problem was obtaining this high quality patient feedback. Several methods of data collection resulted in dead ends. Interviewing patients was time consuming and costly, comments from CAHPS surveys were sparse and incomplete.

Ultimately, the best source of patient feedback is the patients themselves. We ask healthcare consumers to tell their story, to describe and rate recent healthcare encounters. The result: unbiased, unfiltered feedback.  The patient feedback is classified and labeled based on the themes that patients repeatedly mention in their comments.  These themes are used to develop deep learning models, i.e., the company's AI Pipeline, that recognizes and labels what patients are saying about their healthcare experiences.  Labeled patient comments are converted into data analytics based on sentiment and comment types by department.  Results are displayed in interactive dashboards. This allows health systems to understand from the patient's perspective what is going well and what problems are frustrating patients across the total system and/or by department.

However, converting patient feedback to reliable analytics was just the beginning.   It turns out there is a strong relationship between the sentiment expressed by patients and a health system's overall rating. In other words, qualitative feedback is a very accurate predictor of health system performance. But that insight alone is not sufficient. During a client's annual planning cycle, the lean team responsible for improving patient experiences kept asking, "What do we work on next?" Simply using comment frequency and average sentiment is misleading. Many patients may complain bitterly about parking but at the end of the day, it does not influence how they rate their experience.  Using output from the company's AI Pipeline and statistical modeling, PatientsVoices is able to pinpoint what patient reported problems are having the greatest negative impact on their experiences, their ratings and ultimately, health system profitability.

The images that accompany this report show how the patient feedback from one health system, analyzed and reported by PatientsVoices, impacted the organization's priorities, improvement initiatives and ultimately their results.

 


Last Modified: 04/04/2022
Modified by: Mary Kay O'connor
